articles.headline: Goodbye, Nation. Goodbye, Blowhard Self.
articles.snippet: After nine years nurturing his TV persona of a conservative talk show host, Stephen Colbert will bid farewell to the other Stephen Colbert on Thursday.
articles.abstract: After nine years nurturing his TV persona of a conservative talk show host, Stephen Colbert will bid farewell to the other Stephen Colbert on Thursday.
articles.lead_paragraph: For nine years, Stephen Colbert has relentlessly maintained his pompous, deeply ridiculous but consistently appealing conservative blowhard character on his late-night show, “The Colbert Report” — so much so that when he puts the character to rest for good on Thursday night, he may have to resort to comicide. The Grim Reaper is his last guest.

articles.headline: Recalls of Cars Abroad Prompt No Urgency in U.S.
articles.snippet: A Times examination of actions by major United States automakers found different standards for recalls of substantially similar vehicles.
articles.abstract: A Times examination of actions by major United States automakers found different standards for recalls of substantially similar vehicles.
articles.lead_paragraph: Toyota discovered a braking defect, Honda a power steering flaw and Nissan a problem that could lead drivers to lose control of their cars. Ford found that wires in some cars could melt, General Motors that some airbags might fail to deploy, and Chrysler that some of its Jeeps could burst into flames.
articles.byline: By Danielle Ivory and Rebecca R. Ruiz

articles.headline: Slowdown in China Bruises Economy in Latin America
articles.snippet: China’s insatiable hunger for Latin America’s raw materials fueled the region’s most prosperous decade at least since the 1970s. That era is over.
articles.abstract: China’s insatiable hunger for Latin America’s raw materials fueled the region’s most prosperous decade at least since the 1970s. That era is over.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANTIAGO, Chile — Few people are as intensely worried about the slowing Chinese economy as Latin Americans.

articles.headline: Quandary for Sony in Terror Threats Over ‘The Interview’
articles.snippet: As Sony came under pressure to cancel or postpone the release of the film, about the assassination of North Korea’s leader, the New York premiere was called off.
articles.abstract: As Sony came under pressure to cancel or postpone the release of the film, about the assassination of North Korea’s leader, the New York premiere was called off.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Sony Pictures Entertainment, the F.B.I., theater owners and competing film studios scrambled on Tuesday to deal with a threat of terrorism against movie theaters that show Sony’s “The Interview,” a raunchy comedy about the assassination of the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un.
articles.byline: By Michael Cieply and Brooks Barnes

articles.headline: Ecuador Family Wins Favors After Donations to Democrats
articles.snippet: A scion of the Isaías family who was banned from entering the United States had the ban waived after her family poured tens of thousands into Democratic coffers.
articles.abstract: A scion of the Isaías family who was banned from entering the United States had the ban waived after her family poured tens of thousands into Democratic coffers.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI — The Obama administration overturned a ban preventing a wealthy, politically connected Ecuadorean woman from entering the United States after her family gave tens of thousands of dollars to Democratic campaigns, according to finance records and government officials.

articles.headline: Market Turmoil Will Test the Post-Crisis Financial System
articles.snippet: One change is that the banks are stronger today because they rely less on borrowed money to finance their trading and lending.
articles.abstract: One change is that the banks are stronger today because they rely less on borrowed money to finance their trading and lending.
articles.lead_paragraph: Washington has been trying to bolster the financial system for the last five years so it can deal with mayhem in the markets. The turmoil this week will test those rebuilding efforts.

articles.headline: Bond Investors Are Skittish Over Emerging Markets
articles.snippet: The precipitous fall in the Russian ruble has already rattled investors. Concerns are mounting that bond troubles of big energy companies in emerging markets will unleash a new wave of market contagion.
articles.abstract: The precipitous fall in the Russian ruble has already rattled investors. Concerns are mounting that bond troubles of big energy companies in emerging markets will unleash a new wave of market contagion.
articles.lead_paragraph: They were the darlings of global investors.

articles.headline: Google’s Detractors Take Their Fight to the States
articles.snippet: Critics of Google are turning to state attorneys general to push the company to censor illegal content and sites from search results.
articles.abstract: Critics of Google are turning to state attorneys general to push the company to censor illegal content and sites from search results.
articles.lead_paragraph: They have lobbied state attorneys general. They have hired former state attorneys general. They have even helped draft a menacing letter for one state attorney general.
articles.byline: By Nick Wingfield and Eric Lipton

articles.headline: As the Ruble Swoons, Russians Desperately Shop
articles.snippet: As Russia faced a currency crisis that prompted bickering among some top presidential allies, consumers afraid of losing their savings flooded stores, rushing to dump rubles.
articles.abstract: As Russia faced a currency crisis that prompted bickering among some top presidential allies, consumers afraid of losing their savings flooded stores, rushing to dump rubles.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russia faced a snowballing currency crisis on Tuesday that prompted an unusual outburst of public bickering among some top presidential allies, as President Vladimir V. Putin struggled to tame events that had the potential to wreck his reputation as the leader who brought stability and prosperity to this country.
articles.byline: By Neil MacFarquhar and Andrew E. Kramer

articles.headline: Stemming a Tide of Cultural Theft
articles.snippet: Antiquities around the world, but especially in war zones, are increasingly under pressure, leading preservationists to call for more protections.
articles.abstract: Antiquities around the world, but especially in war zones, are increasingly under pressure, leading preservationists to call for more protections.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — They have always been among the spoils of war, alluring in their beauty, tantalizing in their value to dealers, museums and collectors. And after a decade of turmoil, and a longer stretch of willful destruction, the world’s antiquities are in such jeopardy that preservationists are sounding a screeching alarm.

articles.headline: Ruble Crisis Is Testing Russia’s Resources
articles.snippet: The country’s Finance Ministry said it was prepared to sell as much as $7 billion of its foreign currency reserves to support the ruble, which an official called “extremely undervalued.”
articles.abstract: The country’s Finance Ministry said it was prepared to sell as much as $7 billion of its foreign currency reserves to support the ruble, which an official called “extremely undervalued.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Just a couple of months ago, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia confidently told business leaders that the country could withstand the economic storms. If foreign investors continued to withdraw money, he said, the government could simply tap its sizable reserves to help.

articles.headline: U.S. to Restore Full Relations With Cuba, Erasing a Last Trace of Cold War Hostility
articles.snippet: The U.S. will open an embassy in Havana for the first time in more than a half century after the release of an American contractor held in prison for five years, officials said.
articles.abstract: The U.S. will open an embassy in Havana for the first time in more than a half century after the release of an American contractor held in prison for five years, officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Wednesday ordered the restoration of full diplomatic relations with Cuba and the opening of an embassy in Havana for the first time in more than a half-century as he vowed to “cut loose the shackles of the past” and sweep aside one of the last vestiges of the Cold War.

articles.headline: Amazon Not as Unstoppable as It Might Appear
articles.snippet: Despite growing fears of its invincibility, Amazon could be threatened as smartphones transform the way Americans shop and goods are delivered.
articles.abstract: Despite growing fears of its invincibility, Amazon could be threatened as smartphones transform the way Americans shop and goods are delivered.
articles.lead_paragraph: Thanks to its ugly spat with book publishers, Amazon has lately been cast as the abominable boogeyman of American commerce.
